articles.headline: Israeli Raid in Rafah Rescues 2 Hostages and Kills Dozens, Officials Say
articles.snippet: The hostages, who had been held by Hamas, returned to Israel after a military operation that Gazan health officials said killed at least 67 Palestinians.
articles.abstract: The hostages, who had been held by Hamas, returned to Israel after a military operation that Gazan health officials said killed at least 67 Palestinians.
articles.lead_paragraph: Israeli special operations forces raided a building in the southern Gazan city of Rafah early Monday and freed two hostages held by Hamas, the military said, as Israel launched a wave of attacks that killed dozens of Palestinians in the city, according to the Gazan health ministry.
articles.byline: By Patrick Kingsley and Hiba Yazbek

articles.headline: Big Burden of Migrant Influx Strains Denver
articles.snippet: The city has marshaled resources for the new arrivals, but after Congress rejected a deal aimed at slowing the flow of migrants, its support system is starting to buckle.
articles.abstract: The city has marshaled resources for the new arrivals, but after Congress rejected a deal aimed at slowing the flow of migrants, its support system is starting to buckle.

articles.headline: A Tunnel Offers Clues to How Hamas Uses Gaza’s Hospitals
articles.snippet: New evidence shows Hamas operated under Al-Shifa Hospital but falls short of proving Israel’s early claims that there was a command center there.
articles.abstract: New evidence shows Hamas operated under Al-Shifa Hospital but falls short of proving Israel’s early claims that there was a command center there.
articles.lead_paragraph: New evidence shows Hamas operated under Al-Shifa Hospital but falls short of proving Israel’s early claims that there was a command center there.
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg, Ronen Bergman, Aric Toler and Helmuth Rosales

articles.headline: A ‘Democracy Party’ Like No Other: One of the World’s Biggest Elections
articles.snippet: The celebration of the act of casting a vote has particular resonance in Indonesia, which until a few decades ago was a brutal dictatorship.
articles.abstract: The celebration of the act of casting a vote has particular resonance in Indonesia, which until a few decades ago was a brutal dictatorship.
articles.lead_paragraph: The young women and men moved from booth to booth, asking questions about the political hopefuls’ track records and visions for the country. A few steps away, first-time voters practiced casting their ballots in pretend voting booths. And onstage, talk show guests discussed how to make an informed choice in backing a candidate.
articles.byline: By Muktita Suhartono, Sui-Lee Wee and Hasya Nindita

articles.headline: A Key Inflation Gauge Came In Hotter Than Expected Last Month
articles.snippet: Overall prices cooled slightly from a year earlier, but the report included worrying signs for the Federal Reserve.
articles.abstract: Overall prices cooled slightly from a year earlier, but the report included worrying signs for the Federal Reserve.
articles.lead_paragraph: Inflation cooled less than expected in January and showed worrying staying power after volatile food and fuel costs were stripped out — a reminder that bringing price increases under control remains a fraught, bumpy process.

articles.headline: Who Speaks for the President? Depends on Whom You Ask.
articles.snippet: The White House heralded Karine Jean-Pierre as a trailblazing press secretary. But it has increasingly relied on John Kirby, a longtime Washington hand, to spread its message.
articles.abstract: The White House heralded Karine Jean-Pierre as a trailblazing press secretary. But it has increasingly relied on John Kirby, a longtime Washington hand, to spread its message.
articles.lead_paragraph: On the day she was named the first Black and first openly gay White House press secretary, Karine Jean-Pierre said she hoped her appointment might inspire other people who, like her, never imagined occupying the pre-eminent role in political communications.
